title: Social Values and Health Priority Setting: A User Template
abstractText:
Across the world, policymakers face the challenge of setting health care priorities fairly. Priority setting involves technical analyses of clinical and cost effectiveness. However, it also involves social value judgments about, for example, justice, solidarity, respect for persons and dignity as matters of substance, and transparency, accountability and participation as matters of process. These value judgments are often controversial, but they are frequently made implicitly and can go unrecognised in the decision-making process.

This project will develop a template which will be a practical tool to help policymakers in their deliberations around social values in health priority setting. The template will set out the relevant social values and the range of ways in which they can be interpreted, in an intellectually coherent yet practical and accessible way. It aims to be easily adaptable to local circumstances, and to offer a means by which policymakers can more easily identify, articulate and address issues of social values in their decisions. It will enable clearer identification of the values and their social and ethical implications and, as such, will help policymakers to reason more cogently in their deliberations and, ultimately, to render their decisions more socially justifiable.
impactText: The framework developed in the project has been converted into a social values audit tool that is currently being applied and developed as part of a London Collaborations for Leadership in Applied Health Research and Care (CLAHRC) project, run by Professor Peter Littlejohns of KCL Medical School. The intention is that it be applied internally by and externally to decision-making organisations such as CCGs for improved transparency. Healthcare Societal,Policy & public services
findingsText: The object of the award was not to conduct further research but to see whether the general approach developed by modern social contract theory could be applied to a specific area of policy. However, the key insight from the research is that social values, other than benefit maximization, play an important role in determining a justifiable and politically accountable allocation of health care resources. This is set out in various publications associated with the award. I am continuing to collaborate with Professor Peter Littlejohns in on-going work to extend to a wide range of health care commissioners the use of the template. Healthcare
